%md 
#### Count number of rows in wdi_csv_text using Bash and Hive
- fs cache for all nodes is cleared before Hive operation
- fs cache for the master node is cleared before Bash operation
- The Hive operation takes longer (23s) as expected since it has to load files from different nodes into the Hive table and then perform the operation as Tez tasks through YARN
- The Bash operation takes less time (19s) as expected since it can access the files locally and perform the operation directly on the files

In the wdi_gs table, we used the default SerDe with “ROW FORMAT DELIMITED FIELDS TERMINATED BY ‘,’”; therefore this assumes that every line in the file contains 6 fields, all separated by ‘,’;
however, from the result above it is clear that the 4th field of some lines (indicator names) are themselves separeated by ‘,’, which creates 7 fields for those lines; this makes the SerDe place the 2nd part of the indicator name field in the indicator code column of the table, which is not correct.

#### Create a new table with a different SerDe (OpenCSV Serde) from the original data in Google Storage

msg.data: Create a new table with a different SerDe (OpenCSV Serde) from the original data in Google Storage

(year INTEGER, countryName STRING, countryCode STRING, indicatorName STRING, indicatorCode STRING, indicatorValue FLOAT)
ROW FORMAT SERDE 'org.apache.hadoop.hive.serde2.OpenCSVSerde'
WITH SERDEPROPERTIES (
    "separatorChar" = ","
)
STORED AS TEXTFILE
LOCATION 'gs://jarvis_data_eng_andres/datasets/wdi_2016'

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Create a new table to be stored in HDFS from the previously created wdi_opencsv_gs table, which is now correctly parsed; use the same OpenCSV SerDe
As mentioned above, the parsing problem occurs for the lines on the file whose indicator name field is itself separated by ','; the OpenCSV SerDe treats all columns to be of type String and since the problematic fields are of the form "... , ...." including the outer quotes, this SerDe takes everything inside those quotes as a single field (indicator name - see above), which the default SerDe is not able to do; this solves our parsing problem for the indicator name and indicator code columns.

msg.data:
Create a new table to be stored in HDFS from the previously created wdi_opencsv_gs table, which is now correctly parsed; use the same OpenCSV SerDe

As mentioned above, the parsing problem occurs for the lines on the file whose indicator name field is itself separated by ‘,’; the OpenCSV SerDe treats all columns to be of type String and since the problematic fields are of the form “… , ….” including the outer quotes, this SerDe takes everything inside those quotes as a single field (indicator name - see above), which the default SerDe is not able to do; this solves our parsing problem for the indicator name and indicator code columns.

%md
wdi_csv_text performs much faster (23s) than wdi_opencsv_text (47s); this is because:
- wdi_csv_text uses Hive's default SerDe (LazySimpleSerDe); it deserializes fields lazily — only as they are accessed, which provides better performance
- wdi_opencsv_text uses OpenCSVSerDe, which does not make use of lazy deserialization

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Hive Partitions
By partitioning by 'year' for example, records for the same year will be stored in the same partition. The advantage to this scheme is that queries that are restricted to a particular year or set of years can run much more efficiently, because they only need to scan the files containing the partitions that the query pertains to (partitions in a partitioned table are simply subdirectories of that table/directory in HDFS). After partitioning by year, the same query to get Canada's GDP growth rate in 2015 (46s without partitioning), now takes much less time (2s).

After partitioning by year, the same query to get Canada’s GDP growth rate in 2015 (46s without partitioning), now takes much less time (2s).

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Columnar File Optimization
Binary formats can be divided into two categories: row-oriented formats and column-oriented formats. Generally speaking, column-oriented formats work well when queries access only a small number of columns in the table, whereas row-oriented formats are appropriate when a large number of columns of a single row are needed for processing at the same time. Hive thas to read the whole row (line in file) so that it can parse it into columns, even if you just need a subset of the columns in your query. Column-oriented formats store columns as rows; this allows Hive to skip reading the columns of a row not in the SELECT clause, which increases performance. Hive has native support for the Parquet, RCFile, and ORCFile column-oriented binary formats.

msg.data:
Columnar File Optimization

Binary formats can be divided into two categories: row-oriented formats and column-oriented formats. Generally speaking, column-oriented formats work well when queries access only a small number of columns in the table, whereas row-oriented formats are appropriate when a large number of columns of a single row are needed for processing at the same time. Hive thas to read the whole row (line in file) so that it can parse it into columns, even if you just need a subset of the columns in your query. Column-oriented formats store columns as rows; this allows Hive to skip reading the columns of a row not in the SELECT clause, which increases performance. Hive has native support for the Parquet, RCFile, and ORCFile column-oriented binary formats.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Compression Differences
Parquet stores binary data in a column-oriented way, where the values of each column are organized so that they are all adjacent, enabling better compression (the Parquet table is ~90% smaller than its source table.). It is especially good for queries which read particular columns from a “wide” (with many columns) table since only needed columns are read and IO is minimized.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Runtime Differences
As can be seen below, wdi_csv_parquet has much better performance than wdi_opencsv_text; the latter one has to parse every line of the file into all the collumns of the table to be able to answer queries, whereas the former one only reads the columns in the SELECT statement, making more efficient; the less columns we select, the faster it runs. 
**- Count number of rows in table:**                        wdi_opencsv_text = 54s; wdi_csv_parquet = 12s
**- Canada's GDP growth in 2015:**                          wdi_opencsv_text = 49s; wdi_csv_parquet = 20s
**- Canada's GDP growth in 2015 with fewer columns:**       wdi_opencsv_text = 56s; wdi_csv_parquet = 18s

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Highest GDP Growth
Find the highest GDP growth year for each country: 
- Create a view that contains the max gdp growth for each country
- Create a vew that contains gdp growths for each year
- Join these 2 views on their gdp growth columns

HiveQL produces Tez jobs by deafult; the final HiveQL query takes 23s; re-running the same query with SparkSQL takes only 14s (Spark is arguably faster than Tez).

msg.data:
Highest GDP Growth

Find the highest GDP growth year for each country:
- Create a view that contains the max gdp growth for each country
- Create a vew that contains gdp growths for each year
- Join these 2 views on their gdp growth columns

HiveQL produces Tez jobs by deafult; the final HiveQL query takes 23s; re-running the same query with SparkSQL takes only 14s (Spark is arguably faster than Tez).

paragraphs.text: DROP VIEW IF EXISTS highest_gdp_country_view

msg.data: Query executed successfully. Affected rows : -1

paragraphs.text:
CREATE VIEW IF NOT EXISTS highest_gdp_country_view
AS
SELECT countryname, MAX(CAST(indicatorvalue as FLOAT)) maxgdp
FROM wdi_csv_parquet
WHERE indicatorcode = "NY.GDP.MKTP.KD.ZG" AND
        CAST(indicatorvalue as FLOAT) > 0.0
GROUP BY countryname

paragraphs.text:
SELECT countryname, year, c.maxgdp maxgdp
FROM highest_gdp_country_view c
JOIN highest_gdp_year_view y ON (c.maxgdp = y.gdp)
ORDER BY countryname

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Global Sort
Find the GDP Growth for all coutries; sort by countryname and year.

Sorting data in Hive can be achieved by:
**- ORDER BY x:** guarantees global ordering, but does this by pushing all data through just one reducer this is unacceptable for large datasets; you end up with one sorted file as output
**- SORT BY x:** orders data at each of N reducers, but each reducer can receive overlapping ranges of data; you end up with N or more sorted files with overlapping ranges
**- DISTRIBUTE BY x:** ensures each of N reducers gets non-overlapping ranges of x, but doesn't sort the output of each reducer; you end up with N or more unsorted files with non-overlapping ranges
**- CLUSTER BY x:** ensures each of N reducers gets non-overlapping ranges, then sorts by those ranges at the reducers; this gives you global ordering, and is the same as doing (DISTRIBUTE BY x plus SORT BY x); you end up with N or more sorted files with non-overlapping ranges

**Note:** CLUSTER BY is basically a more scalable version of ORDER BY; global ordering can be achieved in parallel by levaraging SORT BY and DISTRIBUTE BY or CLUSTER BY.

Both queries below achieve the same result; the only difference is that by using DISTRIBUTE BY and SORT BY allows us to work with partition and sort columns that are different (eg. DISTRIBUTE BY countryname SORT BY countryname DESC, year):
- 'DISTRIBUTE BY countryname' ensures all rows for the same country go to the same reducer
- 'SORT BY countryname, year' sorts by those 2 columsn (ASC by default) at each reducer 
- 'CLUSTER BY countryname, year' == 'DISTRIBUTE BY countryname, year SORT BY countryname, year' (partition and sort columns must be the same)

Sorting data in Hive can be achieved by:
- ORDER BY x: guarantees global ordering, but does this by pushing all data through just one reducer this is unacceptable for large datasets; you end up with one sorted file as output
- SORT BY x: orders data at each of N reducers, but each reducer can receive overlapping ranges of data; you end up with N or more sorted files with overlapping ranges
- DISTRIBUTE BY x: ensures each of N reducers gets non-overlapping ranges of x, but doesn’t sort the output of each reducer; you end up with N or more unsorted files with non-overlapping ranges
- CLUSTER BY x: ensures each of N reducers gets non-overlapping ranges, then sorts by those ranges at the reducers; this gives you global ordering, and is the same as doing (DISTRIBUTE BY x plus SORT BY x); you end up with N or more sorted files with non-overlapping ranges

Note: CLUSTER BY is basically a more scalable version of ORDER BY; global ordering can be achieved in parallel by levaraging SORT BY and DISTRIBUTE BY or CLUSTER BY.

Both queries below achieve the same result; the only difference is that by using DISTRIBUTE BY and SORT BY allows us to work with partition and sort columns that are different (eg. DISTRIBUTE BY countryname SORT BY countryname DESC, year):
- ‘DISTRIBUTE BY countryname’ ensures all rows for the same country go to the same reducer
- ‘SORT BY countryname, year’ sorts by those 2 columsn (ASC by default) at each reducer
